~~~
library(ggplot2)
~~~
{: .language-r}


~~~
ggplot() + 
  geom_rect(aes(xmin = 1, xmax = 3, ymin = 10, ymax = 15))
~~~
{: .language-r}

<img src="../fig/rmd-01-introduction-first-rect-1.png" title="plot of chunk first-rect" alt="plot of chunk first-rect" width="612" style="display: block; margin: auto;" />

~~~
ggplot() + 
  geom_rect(aes(xmin = 1, xmax = 3, ymin = 10, ymax = 15), 
            fill = "blue")
~~~
{: .language-r}

~~~
ggplot() + 
  geom_rect(aes(xmin = 1, xmax = 3, ymin = 10, ymax = 15), 
            fill = "blue", alpha = 0.4)
~~~
{: .language-r}

<img src="../fig/rmd-01-introduction-add-transparency-1.png" title="plot of chunk add-transparency" alt="plot of chunk add-transparency" width="612" style="display: block; margin: auto;" />
Higher alpha is more opaque (less transparent). 


~~~
ggplot() + 
  geom_rect(aes(xmin = 1, xmax = 3, ymin = 10, ymax = 15), 
            fill = "blue", alpha = 0.4, color = "black")
~~~
{: .language-r}

<img src="../fig/rmd-01-introduction-add-outline-1.png" title="plot of chunk add-outline" alt="plot of chunk add-outline" width="612" style="display: block; margin: auto;" />

~~~
ggplot() + 
  geom_rect(aes(xmin = 1, xmax = 3, ymin = 10, ymax = 15), 
            fill = "blue", alpha = 0.4, color = "black") + 
  theme_void()
~~~
{: .language-r}

<img src="../fig/rmd-01-introduction-blank-canvas-1.png" title="plot of chunk blank-canvas" alt="plot of chunk blank-canvas" width="612" style="display: block; margin: auto;" />


~~~
ggplot() + 
  geom_rect(aes(xmin = 1, xmax = 3, ymin = 10, ymax = 15), 
            fill = "blue", alpha = 0.4, color = "black") + 
  geom_rect(aes(xmin = 2, xmax = 5, ymin = 3, ymax = 10), 
            fill = "orange", alpha = 1, color = "black") +
  theme_void()
~~~
{: .language-r}

<img src="../fig/rmd-01-introduction-two-rectangles-1.png" title="plot of chunk two-rectangles" alt="plot of chunk two-rectangles" width="612" style="display: block; margin: auto;" />
Possible to add each rectangle with a separate line of code (i.e. a separate
call to the `geom_rect()` function), but labor intensive and repetitive.
Instead, we can create a table-like data structure to hold the values we want
to use for each rectangle and iterate through each row of that table with
a single line of code.
